Solomon Duskis wrote:
> 
> 
> 
> I do agree that <forms> fundamentally serve the role of fulfilling 
> HATEOAS.  However, I disagree that they are "simply links with UI 
> attached."  I'd put it a bit differently.  Forms define the exact nature 
> of client interaction.  Note that "Client" doesn't necessarily mean UI; 
> it can also mean programmatic client.  Forms can be used to create 
> hackable GET URL?<queryParam>=<value>, but that's not the default 
> behavior of <forms>; The default is a POST. 
> 
> Forms, IMHO, are severely underused in RESTful service environments.  
> The concept of a server provided request template is a potentially 
> powerful mechanism of providing runtime meta-data about conversation 
> semantics.

Forms are just another media type.

An HTML form is *exactly* the same as XML.  In XML your media type is 
"application/xml" and your template is XSD.  For HTML forms, your media 
type is application/x-www-form-urlencoded and your template is form markup.

That being said, the whole point of this thread by me was to say that 
forms should be mentioned when explaining HATEOAS and that they may be a 
better analogy than mentioning links.  This is because when non-rest 
people think of links they think of surfing information.  When they 
think of forms they think of actually interacting with a server.  I 
guess what I'm saying is that I was trying to find better ways to sell 
HATEOAS as a viable way to model web services.
